title: To Keep or Not to Keep Allergens in the Home

content: To keep or not keep allergens in the home, that is the question. One of the first questions asked when someone is diagnosed with anaphylactic food allergies or is learning to care for someone with anaphylactic food allergies is, “Can I safely keep their allergen in the home?”
Not All Food Allergy Journeys Will Look the Same, and That’s OK

The answer will be different for everyone, and in my opinion, there is no right or wrong answer. It is very subjective. You must do what is best for you and your household. What food allergy life looks like for one will not be the same as for another. That’s OK.
Should you choose to keep allergens in the home, I’ve got some tips and guidelines to help navigate that decision. First, let’s ask some questions to help determine what’s best for you:
What is the physical age, as well as the cognitive capability, of all people in the home?

content: At one point I had five kids aged 10 and under. For many years, my child with anaphylactic food allergies was not developmentally ready to follow simple instructions with not sharing a toothbrush, or sippy cup, for example. As he grew older and was able to follow these simple safety measures, he still had younger siblings that were not able to.

Every household is different, and it’s up to you, what you feel confident in with the combination of people in your home. We evolved, and when we were ready, we slowly allowed some allergens in the home. That has successfully worked for us. He is now a confident, stress-free, and anxiety-free teen that navigates his food allergy world beautifully.
What are the stress and anxiety levels of all involved?

Everyone experiences trauma differently. Trauma can come from a multitude of experiences with food allergies, up to and including anaphylactic reactions. Not all the time, but often, food allergies are diagnosed following an anaphylactic reaction.

For many, they are now not only navigating a food allergy but also healing from trauma, in addition to grief and other feelings that come with a new diagnosis. Consider this in your decision, and as mental health changes, come back to this decision and reassess as you see fit.

sections.heading: What are the home dynamics with everyone’s schedules and daily habits or needs?
content: Do you frequently have visitors? Do you have relatives that live with you that perhaps don’t remember safety measures or otherwise may be forgetful? Do many people participate in meal preparation, or is it typically left to one person? Are there after-school or date night babysitters?
These questions will help you to determine if you feel you can successfully educate, train, and enable success in food allergy safety based on how your household operates.
How would you currently rate the importance of having the allergen in the home, and why?

Is it important to those in your household to learn to function and live with the food allergy present? Is this something they are developmentally ready for? Could this introduction wait? What is everyone’s mental health regarding this potential added stressor? Can baby steps be made to meet your ideal goal?
Take inventory of what you value in regard to your home and food allergy journey, rank these values, and let that guide your decision.

sections.heading: Does the household have the ability to create a safe zone, along with the supplies and the logistical space to be successful?
content: Just as every household is different when it comes to what people make up the group that resides in a home, so too is the literal physical structure or financial ability.
Is it a single-parent household, and how is the allergen being handled at the co-parenting home? Are allergens handled in a unified way between home locations?

Is it a small apartment with little cabinet room? Is there a pantry? Is there a dishwasher, or are all dishes done by hand? Is the refrigerator and freezer space able to accommodate room for allergy-friendly foods to be stored clearly and in a clear and separate space?

These are just some of the questions that logistically may create the need for more innovative thinking to make it work for each household. You can do it, but it may look different, and that’s perfectly fine.

sections.heading: How many allergens are you managing, and how many people have different dietary restrictions? Is it more feasible and less stressful to have everyone on the same diet, same meals?
content: When my son was younger, we were managing his peanut and shellfish anaphylactic food allergies. None of his other four siblings had any food allergies, intolerances, or other dietary restrictions for most of his childhood.

In the last few years, he gained and lost several food allergies. He has a younger sister that gained a dairy intolerance, as well as another younger sister that gained a gluten intolerance. These changes created an evolution for us that changed how we managed allergens in the home. Situations like this may or may not also change what works for you.
The Evolution of What Works for You

One thing to consider is that your decision now can evolve later as the person with food allergies evolves, as the caregiver evolves, and as the household evolves. While there are some hard-and-fast rules for living a safe, whole, full life with food allergies, there are also many guidelines that may differ from person to person.

content: What’s best for one may not be best for another, and that is OK. If you choose to not keep allergens in the home, great! If you choose to keep allergens in the home, also great.
Guidelines to Consider for Keeping Food Allergens in the Home
Should you choose to keep them in the home, here are some guidelines for doing so:
bullets: Ensure the household is trained in label reading.
Separate safe and unsafe food. Consider designating refrigerator, freezer, cabinet, and pantry spaces. A certain shelf on a cabinet or a certain drawer in the fridge, for example.
Label unsafe foods. Permanent markers, color-coded stickers, and other ways of marking items can be helpful in distinguishing.
Have a separate set of utensils, dishes, or cookware for handling safe and unsafe foods as needed.
Consider the sponges, rags, and other kitchen dish-cleaning items as potential issues for cross-contact.
If preparing both a safe and unsafe version of a meal or components of a meal, create the safe meal first to limit chances for cross-contact.
Rinse and put utensils used to prepare unsafe food directly into the dishwasher upon completion of use.
Using a griddle or grill? Use aluminum foil or a clean dedicated pan to avoid cross-contact.
Practice hand washing as a household before and after consuming unsafe foods to avoid transfer of allergens.
Scrub surfaces after preparing foods using hot soapy water.
Educate the household on cross-contact and how it can occur, including but not limited to cutting boards, utensils, can openers, toaster ovens, microwaves, and more.

Take caution with airborne allergens during the preparation process. Boiling and frying foods, such as boiled milk or fried fish, could make cause for concern if the food allergic individual doesn’t keep a safe distance during preparation. An additional safety measure might include waiting a short time before entering the area post-preparation.

Consider household rules that keep individuals from consuming allergens outside the kitchen or other designated area. This may even include assigned seating for household members and guests, with a safe seat and area for the individual with food allergies.

Have all emergency medications and a Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Emergency Care Plan available, as well as all household members trained in recognizing symptoms, where medications are kept, and how they can help respond in the event of a reaction.

content: Though this is not an exhaustive list of questions or guidelines for safety, it should serve to help you get started. Find what works for you and navigate your food allergy journey in a way that you are living a whole, full life with food allergies!
